
<title> Multi Thread Test </title>

A multi-threaded performance test.

Database schema is:

<pre>
      CREATE TABLE tbl(
         a INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
         b BLOB(200),
         c CHAR(64)
      );
      CREATE INDEX tbl_i1 ON tbl(substr(c, 1, 16));
      CREATE INDEX tbl_i2 ON tbl(substr(c, 2, 16));
</pre>

The initial database contains 1,000,000 rows. Column "a" contains values
1 to 1,000,000. Column "b" contains a 200 byte blob value. Column "c"
contains a 64 byte text value.

Each transaction consists of a number of updates and scans. Each update 
modifies exactly one row as follows:

<pre>
      UPDATE tbl SET b=updateblob(b, ?, ?), c=hex(frandomblob(32)) WHERE a = ?;
</pre>

Each scan is:

<pre>
      SELECT * FROM tbl WHERE substr(c, 1, 16)>=hex(frandomblob(8)) ORDER BY substr(c, 1, 16) LIMIT 10;
</pre>

Each test consists of either between 1 and 8 threads running transctions
against an hct database, or a single thread running transactions against an
SQLite database. Each test runs for 30 seconds. SQLite is configured with:

<pre>
      PRAGMA journal_mode = wal";
      PRAGMA wal_autocheckpoint = 10000";
      PRAGMA mmap_size = 1000000000";
      PRAGMA locking_mode = exclusive;
      PRAGMA synchronous = off;
</pre>

Each cell of the table below contains results for two test runs. The values
are the number of attempted transactions per second, followed by the percentage
of those transactions that failed with SQLITE_BUSY in parenthesis, followed by 
the per-cpu speed that this represents relative to the single-threaded case.

For tests with "-sep" in the name, each thread used a separate 1,000,000 row
database (hence the 0.0% SQLITE_BUSY rate for these tests). Tests without
"-sep" have all threads writing to the same database.
